I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Information and Communications Technology (ICT) in Basic Education Project is 
included in the Uzbekistan Country Strategy and Program Update 2005–2006, with project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA) programmed for 2005. In August 2004, the Government 
requested that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) advance the processing of the project in 
support of implementing the National Program for Basic Education Development 2004–2009, 
unveiled in May 2004. A fact-finding mission visited Uzbekistan in October 2004, and reached 
agreement  with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  goal,  purpose,  scope,  implementation 
arrangements, cost and financing plan, and outline terms of reference for consulting services.1 A 
preliminary project framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Expanding  ICT  is  a  strategic  priority  of  the  Government’s  agenda  to  develop  the 
economy  and  increase  the  people’s  well-being.2  An  information-  and  knowledge-based 
economy will enable Uzbekistan to benefit fully from a global economy that is becoming ever 
more  integrated.  Such  an  economy  will  enhance  Uzbekistan’s  competitiveness  within  the 
Central Asia region.3  The Government has made considerable efforts since the new millennium 
to realize this national aspiration. Achievements include development of a national ICT strategy 
in 2002, and issuance of a number of decrees and resolutions to guide strategy implementation 
and set up the necessary agencies and regulatory framework.4 While Uzbekistan scores high on 
education-related Millennium Development Goals, with a net enrolment ratio at 99% and no 
major gender differentials,5 basic education is often of low quality and relevance. International 
experience shows that appropriate use of ICT helps students score high on achievement tests, 
learn more in less time, and develop positive attitudes toward their classes and learning.6 
Uzbekistan sees integrating ICT into learning and teaching as a key to achieving its sector 
reform objective of improving the quality and relevance of basic education.  
 
3.  Education is designated as a key sector in implementing the national ICT strategy, which 
aims to reach a computer-student ratio of 1:20 and provide Internet access to 63% of all schools 
by 2010. Currently, the computer-student ratio is about 1:110, and only 0.2% schools have 
Internet access.7 Over 80% of equipment is outdated. Computers are insufficient even for 
computer classes, let alone for broader integration of ICT into the curriculum. Only 50% of 
schools offer computer classes, and many have no access to computer equipment. A recent 
report8 noted that Uzbekistan is at a very early stage of ICT development, with reference to key 
indicators measuring (i) share of subjects studied with the use of ICT in the total number of

4.  Need for an ICT Development Strategy in Basic Education. There is wide agreement 
among Government agencies that ICT should be used not only to improve computer literacy but 
also,  more important,  to  improve  the  quality and  relevance  of  basic  education in  general. 
However, how the national ICT strategy’s goals can be achieved by 2010 is not articulated. 
Important issues relating to the institutional and policy implications for education, infrastructure 
development and hardware provision, the substantial resource implications for sustainability, 
and the advantages and disadvantages of various options should be understood. A full-fledged 
ICT development strategy should be developed for basic education.  
 
5.  Curriculum,  Testing,  and  Content  Development.  Applying  ICT  in  teaching  and 
learning will require revising the curriculum and developing new syllabi. The current curriculum 
and syllabi show little concern with the development of the kind of competencies and higher-
order thinking skills that would support and be supported by an ICT-based curriculum. To 
develop syllabi within an ICT-based curriculum requires practical experience, of which little 
exists. The national testing and assessment system will need to be adjusted accordingly, and 
greater flexibility in the system may be needed to allow for a gradual and variable approach to 
ICT provision in schools.  
 
6.  Implementation of an ICT-based curriculum requires development of appropriate content 
software and other information resources. This market is poorly developed, with most of what is 
available in English and Russian. In particular, targeted training and reorientation of authors 
toward new approaches and requirements will be needed. Sustained capacity building in this 
regard will help ensure that new learning materials will provide the motivation, ideas, support, 
and guidance needed by students and teachers in applying ICT in schools.  
 
7.  Capacity Building for Teachers, Management, and Technical Support. Success in 
integrating ICT depends critically on sufficient teachers’ capacity, management, and technical 
support, backed by an appropriate incentive system. The Government’s training plan will be 
insufficient to support the introduction of ICT into educational institutions in the 9,727 schools by 
2010  (footnote  2).  Experience  elsewhere  shows  that  school  principals  and  education 
management in general must strongly support the introduction of ICT in schools, as it will bring 
about fundamental changes to the education process, management, and administration. For this 
purpose, management training (at central, oblast, raion, and school levels) in ICT skills and 
applications, new pedagogical approaches, school planning, financial and budget management, 
and community relationships are needed. Adequate technical support will be necessary to 
ensure  effective  use  of  ICT  facilities.  Mechanisms  for  effective  public  and  private  sector 
partnership should be explored for effective technical support for schools within raion and oblast 
networks.  
 
8.  The proposed training is necessary but not sufficient. For successful integration of ICT, a 
system must be in place to provide appropriate incentives for all to adopt, adapt, and change to 
bring progress in learning and teaching through ICT. The Government has recently piloted a 
nationwide system linking teachers’ salaries to performance. This process should be enhanced 
to  address  teachers’  performance  and  career  development-related  issues  linked  with  the 
comprehensive introduction of ICT.  
 
9.  Infrastructure Bottlenecks and Hardware Provision. About 35–40% of the schools do 
not have telephone lines; this and other infrastructure bottlenecks need to be addressed in

3
developing Internet access and usage. In equipping schools with ICT, careful consideration will 
need to be given to (i) appropriate technology—top-of-line computer equipment may not be 
required  everywhere,  and  Internet  access  may  not  be  necessary  at  the  initial  stage;  (ii) 
alternative technology—audio-video and DVD instead of, or complementary to, computers; and 
(iii) provision of adequate technical backup and support. 
 
10.  Achieving  Financial  Sustainability  and  Pro-Poor  Issues.  ICT  is  expensive,  and 
sustainability  will  be  a  key  challenge.  Although  the  Government  has  allocated  significant 
resources  for  purchasing  computers  for  schools  in  2005-2009  (mainly  through  the  School 
Development  Fund,  established  in  June  2004),  how  the  significant  recurrent  and  capital 
replacement costs will be financed is unclear. To ensure sustainability, the Government will 
need to (i) set realistic and reachable objectives, and (ii) make hard budgetary choices among 
competing demands. Cost reduction and recovery strategies and mechanisms may also be 
needed, including building public and private sector partnerships. The Government has put in 
place a number of incentives and pro-poor policies since last year, including exemption from 
value-added tax and a 50% reduction of user charges for ICT firms operating in rural areas. 
However, a comprehensive approach is needed. It will be important to ensure that (i) effective 
mechanisms are in place to protect the poor, particularly if any cost recovery and reduction 
scheme is to be implemented; and (ii) any ICT implementation plan will not enlarge but narrow 
the internal digital divide between high- and low-income groups. An initial poverty and social 
analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
11.   Support by ADB and other Development Partners. ADB support for basic education 
in Uzbekistan has focused on improving the quality and relevance through investments and 
policy and institutional reforms. The project will represent an important step in this partnership 
and is consistent with ADB’s education sector strategy and ICT development strategy. The 
project will benefit from ADB’s experience and lessons learned in ICT development in its other 
member countries. The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) helped the Government 
prepare the national ICT development strategy. An ongoing project supported by the United 
States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  also  has  ICT  development  as  a 
component. The TA will coordinate closely with these development partners.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
12.  The overall goal of the project is to improve the quality and relevance of basic education 
through the integration of ICT. The purpose of the project is to support the introduction of an 
ICT-based approach to teaching and learning in a defined number of grade levels and subjects 
in basic education.  
 
13.  The TA will help the Government prepare an investment project for integrating ICT into 
basic education based on a well-formulated ICT development strategy for basic education. 
Outputs of the TA will include (i) an ICT development strategy in basic education and (ii) a 
feasibility study for a project to integrate ICT in basic education suitable for ADB financing.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The TA will follow a participatory approach to build consensus on key challenges facing 
ICT development in basic education among key government agencies, and other stakeholders, 
including students, parents, teachers, school managers, development partners, and the private

4  
sector. A main focus of the TA will be the development of targeted policies and mechanisms to 
help bridge the internal digital divide. The TA will explore alternatives and mechanisms to 
promote public and private sector partnership in ICT development.  
 
15.  The TA will comprise two streams of activities: the first focusing on developing an ICT 
strategy for basic education, and the second on preparing the feasibility study for the ICT in 
Basic Education Project. The ICT strategy developed will guide nationwide implementation of 
ICT integration in basic education over the medium and long term, and will serve as the anchor 
for the feasibility study. The first stream will begin in March 2005 and a detailed concept 
strategy is expected by April 2005. A draft strategy is expected to be ready by June 2005 for 
formal discussion with the Government. Further refinement of and consultation on strategy 
development will take place at a national conference planned for the fourth quarter of 2005, to 
finalize the strategy. Activities of the first stream will focus on (i) conducting a sector analysis; (ii) 
establishing  medium-  and  long-term  objectives  of  integrating  ICT  in  basic  education  with 
appropriate indicators; (iii) assessing educational policy, institutional, and capacity needs; (iv) 
detailing resource needs within a medium-term budgetary framework with costed alternative 
financing options for achieving affordability and financial sustainability; and (v) developing model 
hardware and facilities profiles in accordance with the medium- and long-term objectives.  
 
16.  The second stream—preparation of a project feasibility study—will begin in April 2005, 
anchored in the concept strategy developed under the first stream. A midterm report of the 
feasibility study will be developed by May 2005, and the draft final report prepared for a tripartite 
meeting on the feasibility study in mid-June 2005. Activities in the second stream will focus on 
(i) detailed economic and financial analysis of ICT integration; (ii) ICT demand and alternative 
project analysis, cost and benefit analysis, and budget impact analysis; (iii) poverty and social 
assessment;  (iv)  financial  management  assessment;  and  (v)  developing  detailed  project 
component  plans,  including  activities,  cost  estimates  and  financing  arrangements,  and 
implementation  arrangements  and  schedules.  The  feasibility  study  will  conform  to  ADB’s 
requirements for a report and recommendation of the President.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total TA cost is estimated at $750,000 equivalent, comprising $486,000 in foreign 
exchange costs and $264,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will cover the entire 
foreign exchange costs and $114,000 equivalent of the local currency costs for a total of 
$600,000.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The 
Government’s  contribution,  estimated  at  $150,000  equivalent,  will  be  in  kind  and  cover 
remuneration of counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative support, and logistics. 
The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The TA will require 43 person-months of consulting services (17 international and 26 
domestic). The international consultants will have expertise in (i) developing ICT strategy in 
basic education; (ii) integrating ICT in learning and teaching, including curriculum and content 
development, and capacity building (teaching and management); (iii) institutional development 
and financial sustainability; (iv) hardware and support; (v) social and poverty analysis; and (vi) 
economic  and  financial  analysis.  ADB  will  engage  a  firm  of  international  consultants  in 
association with domestic consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. Short-listed firms will be required to prepare simplified technical proposals and will

5
be selected using quality- and cost-based selection procedures. Outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
19.  The Ministry of Public Education (MOPE) will be the Executing Agency, with the first 
deputy  minister  as  the  TA  director,  assuming  overall  supervision  responsibility.  MOPE  will 
provide  adequate  office  space  and  office  furniture,  and  will  cover  the  cost  of  utilities  for 
consultants and counterpart staff. The TA will make provision for office supplies, workshops, 
additional support staff, and translation of reports prepared under the TA. The consultants will 
coordinate  closely  with  other  ongoing  ADB  projects,  particularly  the  Education  Sector 
Development Project and the Second Textbook Development Project.9  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from March 2005 to February 2006. The 
consultants will submit inception, interim, draft final, and final reports, each containing two 
distinctive parts (para. 13). In particular, by mid-June 2005, the draft ICT development strategy 
in basic education and the draft feasibility study should be prepared and ready for presentation 
and discussion at a workshop. TA findings will be presented in the interim, midterm, and draft 
final workshops, with participation of all stakeholders, tentatively scheduled for March, May, and 
June 2005, respectively. A conference is scheduled for the fourth quarter of 2005 to finalize the 
ICT development strategy in basic education. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for preparing the Information and Communications Technology 
in Basic Education Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Uzbekistan: Although the project does not intend 
to  have  direct  impact  on  reducing  poverty,  it  will  help  reduce  poverty  by  (i)  creating  an  equitable 
environment for ensuring human development; (ii) setting up a system where educational services are 
accessible in all areas, particularly in rural areas, and help meet the needs of low-income groups; (iii) 
piloting untested initiatives to demonstrate cost-effective, viable, and equitable approaches with a sharp 
focus on equity and poverty reduction; (iv) pursuing innovative, cost-effective approaches and building 
local capacity in content generation to enhance longer term sustainability; (v) providing opportunities to 
complement  on-the-job  training  and  to  offer  continuing  education  for  teachers;  (vi)  broadening  the 
availability  of  quality  educational  materials;  and  (vii)  enhancing  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of 
educational administration and policy. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The poverty and social analysis should do the following: 
•  Show how the project relates to national priorities as identified in the country poverty analysis. 
•  Identify project beneficiaries and the likely barriers to their participation in and benefiting from the project. 
•  Assess affordability of accessing information and communications technology (ICT)-based education for poor 
children. 
•  Assess a geographic profile for piloting ICT in basic education with a pro-poor focus. 
•  Identify how ICT can provide various channels to bring educational options to excluded people, including 
those in rural areas. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?   Yes   No  
The TA will follow a participatory approach—the key to build consensus on strategy development and feasibility 
study—through a series of workshops, seminars, conferences, training, and consultation to be participated in by all 
stakeholders. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?   Yes    No 
A participatory strategy will be developed to promote local capacity and ownership by (i) working with educational 
institutions with expertise in ICT and teacher training, strengthening capacities in developing ICT-based content for 
basic education; (ii) involvement of private firms and individuals in creating ICT applications for basic education; and 
(iii) broader community empowerment through pro-poor focus. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Uzbekistan has achieved gender equality in basic education. The project will develop a strategy to maximize impact 
on women by (i) correcting gender stereotyping regarding ICT software development; (ii) improving access and 
content of educational materials for male and female students, parents, and schools by pioneering the use of the 
Internet; and (iii) discussing, and making strategies on, key gender and education issues.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The main outputs of the technical assistance (TA) are to produce (i) an information and 
communications (ICT) strategy for basic education and (ii) a feasibility study for the ICT in Basic 
Education Project. The TA will be implemented by a team of nine consultants (four international 
and five domestic), whose responsibilities are described below. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Education Sector Strategist (6 person months) 
 
2.  The team leader will do the following:  
 
(i)  Be responsible for the on-time delivery of (a) the final draft ICT in basic education 
strategy, and (b) the feasibility study for ICT in Basic Education Project, presented in 
the  standard  format  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  report  and 
recommendations to the President.  
 
(ii)  Establish, in close consultation with the Ministry of Public Education (MOPE), (a) 
recommendations for priority grade levels and subjects for teaching informatics and 
introducing ICT-based teaching and learning in other curriculum subjects, (b) a 
financially sustainable hardware and software profile for basic education schools to 
support  the  effective  delivery  of  informatics  and  ICT-based  education  in  the 
proposed priority grade levels and subjects, and (c) a geographic profile for piloting 
ICT in basic education with a pro-poor focus. 
 
(iii)  Develop  and  propose  for  approval  a  sustainable  financing  mechanism  for  ICT 
provision  to  basic  education  and  take  lead  responsibility  for  project  strategies 
relating to curriculum and syllabus review and revision and the development of 
learning and teaching materials, software, and information resources to support an 
ICT-based curriculum. 
 
(iv)  Ensure that the ICT in basic education strategy and the project preparatory technical 
assistance  (PPTA)  feasibility  study  focus  on,  and  take  full  account  of,  poverty 
issues,  improve  external  funding  agency  coordination,  and  develop  a  project 
monitoring and evaluation system based on sound methodology. 
 
(v)  Work closely with MOPE and all other Government agencies and stakeholders, and 
provide full training to domestic consultants and counterparts.  
 
(vi)  Collect  baseline  values  of  the  performance  indicators  specified  in  the  project 
framework and of other relevant ones, which will be used in the framework. 
 
(vii)  Ensure that international and domestic consultants and local counterparts fulfill their 
terms of reference. Be responsible for the programming, coordination, and direction 
of the work and specialist inputs in terms of content quality and timing to complete 
the final assignment objectives on time. 
 
(viii)  Have  skills  in  participatory  planning,  research,  and  approaches  to  strategy 
development; present and discuss interim findings, conclusions, recommendations, 
and  proposals  in  informal  meetings  and  consultations  and  planned  workshops, 
seminars,  and  progress  reviews  with  representatives  of  MOPE  and  other 
stakeholders  to  ensure  full  understanding  and  ownership  of  the  emerging  ICT 
strategy in basic education and the feasibility study.

Appendix 4  13 
 
B.  ICT in Basic Education Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will be required to do the following: 
 
(i)  Assess  through  research  and  fieldwork  policies,  strengths,  weaknesses, 
opportunities, and constraints relevant to an ICT-based curriculum in Uzbekistan, 
and use experience from projects in other countries to develop the ICT strategy for 
basic education and prepare the PPTA feasibility study.  
 
(ii)  Assess  ICT  knowledge  and  skills  in  schools  and  current  teacher  training  and 
retraining  initiatives  (including  distance  education),  support  services,  and 
management structures. 
 
(iii)  Review and recommend (a) teacher training and upgrading strategies in the short, 
medium, and long term, with implementation strategies and schedules; (b) the role 
of  distance  education  in  teacher  and  technician  education  for  ICT,  with 
implementation strategies and schedules; (c) the minimum teacher support services 
required to implement an ICT-based curriculum initiative; (d) minimum school and 
raion operational budgets needed to deliver informatics and ICT-based teaching and 
learning in specified grades; and (e) the management structure and management 
training needs (including school management and leadership training) required to 
implement, supervise, and evaluate ICT objectives in basic education. 
 
(iv)  Assess  staff  remuneration  and  propose  an  incentive  structure  to  support  the 
recruitment and retention of ICT specialist teachers and technicians, particularly in 
rural and remote areas. 
 
(v)  Review the overall basic education curriculum and syllabi and (a)  the suitability of 
the existing curriculum and syllabuses as vehicles for learning through ICT; (b) 
suggest  amendments  in  curriculum  and  syllabus  design  to  establish  a  suitable 
framework for teaching and learning through ICT; (c) prioritize subjects and grade 
levels where ICT-based curriculum work could be phased in; (d) recommend the 
minimum hardware profile needed to deliver informatics and ICT-based approaches 
for  specified  grades  and  subjects;  and  (e)  propose  implementation  plans  and 
schedules. 
 
(vi)  Assess the availability and suitability of learning and teaching materials, software, 
and information resources available in Uzbek, English, Russian, and French to 
support objectives in informatics teaching and in teaching and learning through ICT. 
Suggest  strategies  and  implementation  plans  to  speed  up  the  development  of 
materials in Uzbek, and provide costing and schedule for implementation. 
 
(vii)  Assist the team leader as required, including by providing inputs into the design of a 
monitoring and evaluation system; training domestic consultants and counterparts; 
and assisting in the presentation and discussion of interim findings, conclusions, 
and recommendations at informal meetings, workshops, and seminars.  
 
C.  Economics and Financial Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will be required to do the following:

(i)  Assess  through  fieldwork  and  research  policies,  strengths,  weaknesses, 
opportunities, and constraints relevant to informatics teaching and an ICT-based 
curriculum in Uzbekistan, and use experience from projects in other countries in 
developing the ICT strategy for basic education and preparing the PPTA feasibility

based investments relative to other needed educational investments in the sector, 
with particular reference to poor, rural, and remote schools.
